posts.text:
I've been reflecting on the MIT State of AI in Business 2025 Report and drawing parallels to my experience with MIT's Management project in the 1990s. The insightful dialogues I had with scholars and business leaders back then resonate with the current discussions. It's interesting to see how ideas from my 1994 article in the Sloan Management Review still hold relevance today.  I hope my observations add a new dimension to the ongoing conversations about embracing the agentic web to unlock business value. One thing is clear: we are in the very early stages of Agentic AI, and it is premature to declare successes and failures. 
 #SloanManagementReview #MIT #digitaltransformation John Henderson Jim Ciriello John Sviokla Benn Konsynski Paul Carlile Nitin Joglekar Sowmyanarayan Sampath Venkat Srinivasan Don Bulmer #AgenticAI

author.description: Professor Emeritus at Boston University Questrom School of Business, Author of "The Digital Matrix" (2023), and co-author of "Fusion Strategy" (2024).

posts.text: We celebrated Hal Varian's retirement today, a truly remarkable individual who embodies humility, curiosity, and profound thoughtfulness. He has a rare gift for demystifying complex concepts, making the world more understandable to everyone. More than that, Hal always treated every person he encountered as if they held the potential to change the world, including me, and that made all the difference. I'm incredibly grateful for the many years I had the privilege of working with him. He truly is truly an inspiration.

author.description: Senior Director @ Google | Regulatory Affairs, Antitrust

posts.text:
Calling all new(ish) antitrust, data privacy and data protection scholars: Mark your calendars! Submissions are due for the Next Generation of Antitrust, Data Privacy & Data Protection Scholars Conference on October 31, 2025. The conference will be hosted at the lovely USC Gould School of Law in January. This is an excellent opportunity for real feedback on your draft from senior experts. We hold the conference every two years and it is a really great interdisciplinary conference for junior scholars.  

The Next Generation of Antitrust, Data Privacy & Data Protection Scholars Conference provides an opportunity for professors in law, economics, accounting, finance, management, information system, operations management, and marketing who began their full-time tenure-track career in or after 2018 to present their latest research. Senior scholars and practitioners in the field will comment on the papers. 

Academic papers should be in draft form and not published. Please submit them to dsokol@usc.edu by October 31, 2025.

https://lnkd.in/g8SzXSba

We hold the conference every two years.  Here is the program from our last conference: https://lnkd.in/gd2A9X4j

#aba
#antitrust

author.description: Professor at USC Gould School of Law and USC Marshall School of Business

posts.text:
I just published a fun project in Scientific Reports, titled "Cross-lingual effects of AI-generated content on human work." It was motivated by some frustrating and funny moments of me using popular LLMs in Chinese and Japanese last year. One-liner: AI-generated content could be creating a linguistic divide that widens the productivity gap for the world’s 80% non-English speakers.

Specifically, this research examines the quality of AI-generated content across English, Arabic, and Chinese, and its implications for workers using it.

💡 Key Findings:

- 𝗖𝗿𝗼𝘀𝘀-𝗟𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗗𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀 in LLM output: business recommendations generated using ChatGPT-4 were of significantly lower quality (less complete, actionable, and creative) in Arabic and Chinese compared to English.

- 𝗛𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗜𝘀 𝗔𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗲𝗱: In a randomized experiment with 480 participants, I found that using AI assistance led to less actionable and creative work from Arabic and Chinese speakers compared to their English-speaking counterparts.

- 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗲𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘁𝘆: That disadvantage was especially pronounced for more technical tasks, like R&D, which are crucial drivers of economic growth. Non-English speakers were particularly disadvantaged when dealing with these tasks.

🌍 Big Picture 🌍

We often hear about AI’s potential to uplift less advantaged workers, but this research shows it could reinforce the dominance of English-speaking populations in the global workforce. It has implications for the world’s users, builders, and policymakers. We need more language-inclusive models to make AI’s benefits accessible to everyone, everywhere.

What are your experiences using LLMs in non-English settings (especially in low- and medium-resource languages)? I’d love to hear your thoughts and anecdotes.

Read the full open-access paper here: https://lnkd.in/eg5M7CS2
#Languages #ArtificialIntelligence #GenerativeAI #LLM #TechEquity #Globalization

author.description: Assistant Professor at Johns Hopkins

posts.text:
Generative AI has made it easier than ever to flood the Internet with synthetic yet highly realistic content — what some call “AI slop.” This raises a key question: how does such a new information environment affect trust in news sources, including trustworthy ones?

In a new working paper (with Filipe Campante, Ruben Durante, and Dr. Felix Hagemeister), we study this question and show that in the age of “AI slop,” trust in the news may fall, but demand for trustworthy sources can still rise. 

In partnership with leading German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung (SZ), we ran a field experiment with thousands of readers. Participants were randomly assigned to a treatment or control group. Individuals in the treatment group had to distinguish real images from AI-generated ones, while those in the control group answered questions about real images only. This simple intervention increased concern about misinformation by 0.3 standard deviations and slightly reduced trust (by 0.1 s.d.) across a range of outlets, including SZ itself.

Yet, readers engagement with and attachment to SZ moved in the opposite direction: daily visits to SZ’s digital content rose by 2.5% immediately afterward, and subscriber retention increased by 1.1% over the following five months (a one-third drop in attrition).
These patterns are consistent with a simple model in which the value of credible news rises when misinformation is widespread, boosting engagement even as trust in all outlets declines.

The takeaway: when AI-generated misinformation floods the information space, the relative value of credible news may grow enough to boost readership, even if trust takes a hit. 

Link to the paper: https://lnkd.in/eH9eHxEJ

🚨 Big week in AI. Four major updates, one clear signal: the AI frontier is rapidly opening up — and transforming.

🔓 OpenAI launches gpt-oss: two open-weight language models (120B and 20B) that rival their closed counterparts on reasoning, coding, and health benchmarks. These models are available under the Apache 2.0 license and optimized for on-device deployment. With safety at the forefront, OpenAI even adversarially fine-tuned the models to test worst-case misuse scenarios — a first-of-its-kind for open model releases.

🌍 Google DeepMind unveils Genie 3, a real-time world model capable of simulating rich, navigable 3D environments from a single text prompt. It marks a leap toward embodied agents and AGI training grounds — combining physics modeling, long-horizon memory, and interactive world events at 24 fps.

🧠 Claude Opus 4.1 is here, and it’s a sharp upgrade in code generation and agentic tasks. With 74.5% on SWEbench Verified, it edges out Claude 4 and solidifies Anthropic’s place in agentic reasoning. Companies like GitHub and Rakuten are already reporting real-world value for debugging and research tasks.

🧧 Geopolitical backdrop: This push toward openness isn’t just about access — it’s strategic. OpenAI’s release comes amid competition from China’s DeepSeek and others, as nations and companies race to define the next-gen open AI stack.

💡 Takeaway: We’re entering a new era where openness, capability, safety, and geopolitics intersect. Whether you're building tools, researching safety, or thinking about AI’s societal role — the stack is shifting fast.

Which of these breakthroughs are you most excited about? Let’s discuss 👇

#AI #OpenSourceAI #GenAI #gptOSS #Claude #Genie3 #AGI #AIOpenModels

author.description: Professor at IESE Business School

posts.text:
There’s a lot of buzz and real debate about whether AI is helping software engineers or just giving them more noise to clean up.

My team has been focused on this. Engineering is at the heart of AI development, and early use cases matter. Tools like Cursor and Windsurf are building for this moment. But the research is still mixed. For instance, a recent study from METR found that in some cases, and under some conditions, AI tools can actually slow developers down. At the same time, an earlier study from Microsoft showed significant gains (links below).

That’s why we’ve been learning from the team at Jellyfish, a developer operations platform that works with over 500 companies, representing tens of thousands of engineers. Their data lets us take an early look at how AI tools like OpenAI's Codex are reshaping workflows. While we are working on more conventional research designs, including RCTs, analyzing observational data is a great way to get an early signal on what’s happening. 

What we found:

📈 Teams that use AI ship more code, faster
When teams of any size have a majority of their developers using AI, they show an increase on the order of 1-2 more pull requests (PRs) each week per engineer, compared to a baseline of 1.4 PRs per engineer.

These teams also were moving faster, saving ~4 hours per cycle time from initial Jira ticket to the code being merged to production, compared to a baseline of 16.7 hours. Digging deeper into the data, we see that a proportion of PRs go from taking two days to being sped up to same-day resolutions.

⚠️ But code quality raises questions
While there were significant gains for team speed and output, we also see a very small increase in the number of PRs that are reverted due to errors. These “revert PRs” increase by about 1 in 50. 

We also are seeing more bugs being squashed, with an increase of 1 bug fixed for every 10 engineers. But, it’s unclear if AI is creating new bugs or helping teams finally clear their backlog.

👀  AI tools still need human judgment to deliver quality at speed
Developers are spending more time reviewing and less time writing code. That’s a shift in task allocation and a reminder that speed doesn’t replace the need for discernment.

We’re still early. Observational data like this doesn’t tell the full story. There can be other factors at play that muddy the results, which is why experiments remain a gold standard. However, as we collectively are making sense of this new technology and the shifting nature of work, findings like these add to the growing body of research, experience, and shared intuition that shape our understanding of AI’s impact. 

METR study: https://lnkd.in/e_m3CDkV 
Microsoft study: https://lnkd.in/e2VG38Cz 
More from Jellyfish: https://lnkd.in/e7zWipJ3

author.description: Science of Science and Innovation | Assistant Professor | University of Michigan

posts.text:
New working paper out today! Tim Bresnahan, Pai-Ling Yin, and yours truly.    New Economic Forces Behind the Value Distribution of Innovation

Check out the abstract and the paper (links below): 

Advances in a general-purpose technology (GPT) enable many firms to invent complementary inventions, or co-inventions, making the GPT more valuable. This study examines the empirical implications of a straightforward model in which firms choose either incremental or novel co-invention. Incremental co-inventors aspire to small gains at low costs and with less uncertainty. Novel co-inventors introduce new products or services with the potential for large returns, but do so at high costs and with uncertain outcomes. Similar firms investing in incremental co-invention will create value proportional to their existing business, a benchmark we illustrate with the experiences at local radio and newspapers. The study then examines the value of co-inventions for the World Wide Web and mobile ecosystems, focusing on success in 2013, using data from many sources. This data supports analysis comparing the incremental and novel regimes. The latter should display a distinctly different up! per tail of the distribution of returns. We show that the value distributions for incremental and novel co-invention are far apart. Incremental co-invention is more widely distributed across regions, industries, and firms. Success from novel co-invention is rare, challenging, and the source of the largest value. In the aggregate, novel co-invention creates the most value, so the overall value distribution remains concentrated in a few industries, regions, and firms.   

https://lnkd.in/ew6UHk3v

article.title: New Economic Forces Behind the Value Distribution of Innovation
article.subtitle: nber.org

author.description: Professor at Harvard Business School

posts.text:
The second iteration of my PDW, Gen AI: Innovation and Competitive Strategies #AOM2025, went well, thanks to the amazing speakers: Jay Barney, Scott Stern, Emily Cox-Pahnke, Léonard Boussioux, and Miaomiao Zhang. It was unfortunate that Julian Birkinshaw, Gautam Ahuja, and Kevin B. couldn't join due to unavoidable conflicts, but they were also tremendously helpful in organizing this PDW. 

Most of all, I'm truly grateful to everyone who attended. I believe PDWs only create value through the active participation of attendees, those who take the time to engage, absorb, and carry forward the ideas sparked in these discussions.

The motivation for this PDW stems from my dissertation (guided by Rahul Kapoor, David Hsu, and Andy Wu), which studies how firms' knowledge strategies shape the direction of innovation in emerging technologies, especially general-purpose technologies like AI. I feel fortunate to connect with so many others who share this interest and curiosity. There's still so much to explore as the technology rapidly unfolds and our research continues to grow. The first iteration in 2024 already sparked critical ideas (thanks to Frank T. Rothaermel, Ron Adner, Gary Dushnitsky, Michael G. Jacobides, Prithwiraj Choudhury, Chuck E., and Doyoon Kim), and this year's discussion has pushed the conversation even further.

Thank you again to everyone who made this possible. I look forward to the third iteration in 2026!

author.description: PhD Candidate at the Wharton School

posts.text:
I’m deeply honored to receive the STR Division’s Outstanding Dissertation Award at this year’s Academy of Management Annual Meeting in Copenhagen.
It’s striking how close happiness and hardship can sometimes be. One moment you’re on your honeymoon, the next you’re facing surgery after a scooter accident. During a difficult recovery with post-surgery complications, I was genuinely moved by the many kind messages and congratulations that came with this award.
At the same time, I was sad not to be able to receive the award in person, but I’m incredibly grateful nonetheless. My sincere thanks to Wu, Brian, for organizing, and to the entire AOM STR - Strategic Management Division for this recognition. Special thanks to my supervisor and friend Joost, the UCL School of Management, and my colleagues at IE University—all of whom support me in doing the job I love. I will make sure to adequately celebrate as soon as I can stand on two legs again!

author.description: Assistant Professor of Strategy at IE Business School

posts.text:
I weighed in on Meta's massive hiring spree of top AI talent for Channel News Asia (link in comments)

What's notable to me are two things:
1) The folks Meta is hiring aren't only really good at AI, they are also seasoned managers/ CEOs.
2) Meta has gone all in on this -- it seems a dramatic reversal from the low cost, open source strategy they had been taking.

Big questions I have:
1) How is Meta going to get these folks to work together? It's not easy!
2) What are the details of these $100M pay packages?  I'm reminded of NFL free agency, where headline dollar figures are big, but all that matters is the guaranteed money...

#Meta #AI

posts.text:
🚀 We’re hiring: Multiple positions in Information Systems & Innovation @ LSE
 
The Department of Management is filling several new roles in the Information Systems & Innovation (ISI) Group—one of the world’s oldest hubs for socio-technical research on digital innovation.
 
We’re looking for ambitious and innovative scholars who:
• investigate how digital technology shapes—and is shaped by—organisations, markets, institutions and society
• blend strong theoretical foundations with rigorous qualitative, econometric or computational methods
• publish (or are on track to publish) in top-tier journals and articulate a clear future research agenda
• teach effectively on undergraduate and postgraduate programmes
 
About us:
• 10 full-time faculty + 2 fellows with diverse interests and backgrounds
• Deep links across LSE and with global partners
• Vibrant, interdisciplinary environment in the heart of London
 
A formal advertisement with full details will appear soon. Meanwhile, Prof. Youngjin Yoo (y.yoo@lse.ac.uk) and Prof. Edgar Whitley (E.A.Whitley@lse.ac.uk) will both attend the Academy of Management Annual Meeting, Copenhagen (25-29 July)—contact us or say hello in person to learn more.  Ela Klecun, Anuschka Schmitt and Tomislav Karačić from the group are also at AoM.
 
#AcademicJobs #DigitalInnovation #InformationSystems #LSE

posts.text:
I am delighted to announce we have opened a Tenure-track Position in Strategic Management (Organization Theory) at IESE Business School.

The Strategic Management Department of IESE Business School invites applications for a tenure-track position (Assistant/Associate Professor) for our Barcelona or Madrid campus. The expected start date is September 2026.
We welcome candidates with a strong background in organization theory, economic sociology, or related disciplines, and research interest in the field of strategic management. We are especially interested in candidates studying phenomena related to the areas of research we prioritize in the department: innovation, AI, sustainability, and global leadership and organization. 

More details on the IESE Strategic Management department can be found at 
https://lnkd.in/dTe6AaNQ

IESE Business School is one of the world’s leading business schools, with a vibrant research community and campuses in Barcelona, Madrid, Munich, New York City, and São Paulo. 

If interested, please apply by September 15th, 2025 through the following link: 
https://lnkd.in/dNZ5Gjt8

Please contact Carolina Dolz (cdolz@iese.edu) or any member of the recruiting committee for inquiries and/or additional information. 

The Recruiting Committee
Fabrizio Ferraro, Marta Elvira, Giovanni Valentini

It's official! I am happy to report my promotion to Associate Professor with tenure at the University of Toronto. It has been a long journey, and I could not have made it without my co-authors, colleagues, and friends in this wild and woolly profession. (Not to mention my family and "normal" friends!). I'm so grateful to everyone who supported me and my work along the way. 

Looking forward to the next chapter.

I'm looking forward to working with all of the world-class researchers there to continue pursuing my research on AI, open source, and technology strategy.

In this new role, I will continue my work with The Linux Foundation and look forward to bringing these two leading technology institutions closer together!

post.text:
🎙️ Announcing a New Podcast Series! – Private Innovation in the Public Interest with Burnes Center Senior Fellow and Professor Anita McGahan

How can we re-invent corporate responsibility to serve the public good? Join Anita McGahan, Professor and Burnes Senior Fellow, for Private Innovation in the Public Interest, a new podcast exploring how corporate leaders can drive meaningful social change. The first three episodes feature:

Episode 1: Do Something! Do Anything! But Please do it with a Clear Heart and Open Mind. Professor Subramanian Rangan of INSEAD highlights the transformative power of humility, good intentions, continuous learning, clarity of purpose, and, above all, decisive action.

Episode 2: Let’s Right Wrongs that are Readily Fixable - And do it now.  Professor Leandro S. Pongeluppe of The Wharton School discusses how online retailers charge higher prices in poorer areas of Rio’s favelas compared to wealthier neighborhoods just steps away. He’s optimistic that this can change – and gently demands that it should happen now.

Episode 3: Get Strategic by Scaling Up to Well-Tested Approaches. Professor and Dean Emeritus Roger Martin of University of Toronto - Rotman School of Management encourages company leaders to address critical public problems by leveraging their strengths: scaling proven solutions into profitable and sustainable business models.

Listen now: https://lnkd.in/e7Jy7eYe

New episodes drop every week! Coming Soon: Pi-Squared Workshop Series launching Spring 2025—live workshops on reimagining corporate social responsibility and fostering collaboration between companies, NGOs, and governments. 📣 Sign up for updates: https://lnkd.in/geRpxj4x

author.name: The Burnes Center for Social Change

comments.comment: That's great news, Andrea. Congratulations. - Kevin

post.text:
I am honored to receive the *SRF Research in Strategic Management Grant* alongside friends\colleagues Sarath Balachandran and Lisa Tang.

We are exploring the technological transformation underway in the global mobility ecosystem. After a century of stability, this space is being fundamentally reshaped by a wave of disruptive technologies, collectively known as #CASE: #connectivity, #automation, #sharing, and #electricity. We study how OEMs are adapting to this shift, how tech companies are entering the space, and how startups are beginning to make their mark.

This work is largely inspired by long-standing and ongoing conversations with many colleagues, especially Ken Boyer, John Paul MacDuffie, Frank T. Rothaermel, Nicolaj Siggelkow, and Harbir Singh.

We are grateful to the The Strategic Management Society, especially co-chairs Mahka Moeen and Francisco Polidoro, and program director Gary Dushnitsky. Plus, I am personally thankful to Aravind Chandrasekaran, Ben Tepper, and The Ohio State University Fisher College of Business for supporting this application.

Congratulations to fellow awardees Shinjinee Chattopadhyay, Anil Doshi, and Ambre Nicolle!

https://lnkd.in/dPuXPDJ4

#automotive #mobility #Mark3 #gobucks #avantitutta

author.description: Research @ Ohio State University

post.text:
Wonderful conversation with Anita McGahan which picked up on our Point-Counterpoint exchange in the Journal of Management Studies. 

We talked about the *big* issues--the importance of economic growth, inequality, the role of private sector innovation in contributing to a more sustainable future, the perils of the "entrepreneurial state" ... all in less than 30 minutes 😉 

We certainly didn't agree on everything, but there was clearly some common ground. (Anita has provided a nice written summary, interpretation of our convo). 

Thanks for doing this, Anita!

Link: https://lnkd.in/deSXt8Hh

post.text:
📢 New Talking About Platforms Episode: Platform and Innovation System Design with the fantastic Kevin B.! 📢

In this episode, we discuss the evolution of platforms from technology-focused systems to dynamic digital ecosystems. Kevin emphasizes that platforms transform modern firms through scalability, modularity, and data-driven management.

Key themes:
1. AI & Data: Platforms are now data-rich environments where AI, humans, and machines collaborate. LLMs are changing how platforms operate, creating both opportunities and challenges.

2. Existing Companies: Kevin argues that established companies can leverage platform mechanisms and data to create and capture value - very much in line with what Daniel Trabucchi and Tommaso Buganza call Platform Thinking

3. Platform Design: Network effects are not automatic; they result from intentional design, particularly in designing interactions within the ecosystem. Platform design should incorporate data science and AI.

4. Platform Culture: A platform's culture includes shared norms, expectations, and beliefs.

This episode is a must-listen for anyone interested in digital transformation, platform strategy, and the future of business.

🎧 Listen now [Link in the comments]
#platforms #AI #digitaltransformation #innovation #business #podcast

author.description: Dr. rer. pol. | Head of Project Delivery and Partnerships at Peregrine.ai | Business Designer | Researcher | Co-Host Talking about Platforms Podcast

post.text:
We’ve launched "Techwork"!

Today, we kicked off this brand-new elective at INSEAD designed to dive deep into what makes the (digital) tech industry unique from a management perspective.

Co-taught by an academic (me) and an industry expert (Martin Gonzalez), this isn't your typical classroom experience. It's an intense, fast-paced sprint: 21 hours of class packed into 8 days; 3 news cases; 6 guest speakers and a finale visit to Google campus. 

Challenging? Absolutely.
Exciting? Even more so.

We're thrilled to explore the intersection of theory and practice with our students. Let’s go!

#INSEAD #Techwork #DigitalLeadership #Innovation #TechManagement

author.description: Roland Berger Chair Professor of Strategy & Organization Design at INSEAD

comments.comment: This must feel great. Congratulations, Lori.

post.text:
I'm proud and excited to announce #UnstoppableEntrepreneurs - my first book!
 
One of the biggest highlights of my ten years in Vice Dean roles at The Wharton School is meeting our many prolific entrepreneurs, both alumni and students. Innovative Penn students across the university come to Venture Lab hungry to create value and impact, and entrepreneurial Penn alumni support them with time, talent, and treasure.
 
I'm continually amazed by this vibrant Penn entrepreneurial ecosystem. Our entrepreneurs follow varied paths, from disruptors to funders to intrapreneurs, and they represent varied backgrounds and interests across industries, goals, and demographics. This range contrasts sharply to the entrepreneurial stereotype so prevalent in the media, so it's time to promote new role models who generate inspiration for all.
 
That's why I wrote "Unstoppable Entrepreneurs: 7 Paths for Unleashing Successful Startups and Creating Value through Innovation." It shares the stories of seven incredible, resilient, and successful entrepreneurs following different entrepreneurial paths. It's packed with insights, strategies, statistics, illustrations, and tools to inspire your entrepreneurial endeavors, whether they're already underway or just getting started!
 
Wharton School Press will publish Unstoppable Entrepreneurs on April 22 and it is now available for pre-order at https://lnkd.in/emDApXtH. Please spread the word!
 
#entrePENNeur
The Wharton School
Venture Lab
Mack Institute for Innovation Management

post.text:
I am proud to share that I have been promoted to the rank of (Full) Professor at HEC Paris.

Additionally, I will be taking on the role of Management and HR Department Coordinator.

I am incredibly grateful for the exciting projects on the horizon. Thrilled to continue collaborating with my amazing co-authors to further explore the publicization of organizational wrongdoing, among other topics. And looking forward to the first HEC Paris-Rice University Conference on the Organizational Underworld in Paris, as well as the third Workshop on Digital Data for Organization Studies in Milan (both next June).

Also working on some (very cool) teaching initiatives with my fantastic colleagues at HEC Paris.

Stay tuned for more updates!

author.description: Professor of Strategic Management

post.text:
Always a great moment when a student publishes his first paper under your supervision!!! Even better when it comes with important data to answer questions on higher education 😁 

Our paper, Course-Skill Atlas, maps syllabi to labor market skills. We find that higher education institutions are teaching skills more similar to what is being demanded in the labor market over time. Soon, we hope to understand how individual skills taught affect earnings. Check out the dataset and please feel free to reach out to Alireza Javadian Sabet if you have any questions!

author.description: Assistant Professor at Chapman University

post.text:
In product design, innovation is driven by creativity, diversity, and the ability to envision products that stand out in both function and form. As designers face the challenge of pushing boundaries while addressing user needs, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to revolutionize the design process. Pleased to share a new Design Studies paper that proposes a new GAN architecture designed to improve novelty and diversity in product design. Congratulations to co-authors Parisa Ghasemi, Chenxi Yuan, and Mohsen Moghaddam. https://lnkd.in/eKkpsyhm 

Why Novelty and Diversity Matter in Product Design:

Designers are tasked with producing novel concepts that offer more than just functional solutions—they need to inspire, delight, and stand apart in crowded markets. Novelty refers to the uniqueness of a design, while diversity captures the range of design possibilities. Both are crucial in early-stage product ideation, where a wide variety of options can lead to breakthrough innovations.
However, producing a large volume of high-quality, diverse design options manually can be time-consuming and limited by human bias. This is where GenAI comes into play.

The Role of GANs in Increasing Novelty and Diversity:

Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are a powerful AI tool that can generate an array of design concepts more quickly and efficiently than diffusion models. By learning from large datasets of existing products, GANs can create visually appealing and realistic samples, which are required for the later stages of design and engineering beyond pure ideation. More importantly, they have the potential to introduce creative elements that go beyond the limits of the training data. In our recent work on design concept generation (DCG) using GANs, we've seen promising results in how these AI models can increase the novelty and diversity of generated designs, unlocking new possibilities for designers to explore.

Traditional GANs focus primarily on producing realistic outputs by mimicking patterns from training data. However, the next generation of GAN architectures incorporates additional evaluators for novelty and diversity, ensuring that the generated designs are unique, varied, and customizable. This shift toward multi-objective learning is key for real-world applications, especially in fields like fashion, consumer products, and architecture, where aesthetic and functional diversity is essential. 
#design #innovation

post.text:
I am incredibly honored to have been awarded The 2024 Practice of Entrepreneurship Award from the Academy of Management Entrepreneurship Division for my work in launching and growing FamilyBusiness.Org - which has become the leading website in the world dedicated to supporting and educating family businesses.

A special thank you to Dick Schulze, the Founder of Best Buy, and the Richard M. Schulze Family Foundation for their support and encouragement! Also, a very big thank you to David Deeds and James Wetherbe for bringing me on board EIX | Entrepreneur & Innovation Exchange and seeing the opportunity for FamilyBusiness.Org!

Also, thank you to our many journal collaborators who entrust us with their research translations - Journal of Business Venturing, Entrepreneurship Theory and Practice, Strategic Entrepreneurship Journal, Family Business Review, and Journal of Family Business Strategy - and soon to join us - Journal of Small Business Management.

Thank you to our amazing board and team, especially Catherine Buday, Jon Eckhardt, David Townsend, Adam Lofquist, Jennifer Gessner,  Daniel Forbes, and Mathew (Mat) Hughes.

Finally, a big thank you to the wonderful leadership team of the AOM ENT Division, including Jon Carr, Maija Renko, Rachida Justo, Ken Grant, April Franco, Vishal Gupta, Christina Theodoraki, Maribel Guerrero, and Anne-Sophie Sabbatucci. Thank you for this incredible honor - I am almost speechless 😊 
#award #familybusiness #entrepreneurship
